qas.question: What is the only device with dual ported transformer circuit topology?

answers.text: both ports independently excited with no short-circuited port

qas.question: How does a brushless wound rotor achieve stability?

answers.text: a multiphase slip-ring-brush assembly to propagate limited power to the rotor winding set

qas.question: What is the theoretical maximum of a brushless wound rotor?
What is the only device with triple ported transformer circuit topology?

plausible_answers.text: both ports independently excited with no short-circuited port
multiphase slip-ring-brush assembly to propagate limited power to the rotor winding set

qas.question: How doesn't a brushless wound rotor achieve stability?
What isn't the theoretical maximum of a brushless wound rotor?

context: The <a0_0><b4_0>brushless wound-rotor<b4_0/><a0_0/> synchronous doubly-fed (BWRSDF) machine is the only electric machine with a truly dual ported transformer circuit topology (i.e., <a1_0><b5_0>both ports independently excited with no short-circuited port<b5_0/><a1_0/>). The dual ported transformer circuit topology is known to be unstable and requires <a2_0>a <b6_0>multiphase slip-ring-brush assembly to propagate limited power to the rotor winding set<b6_0/><a2_0/>. If a precision means were available to instantaneously control torque angle and slip for synchronous operation during motoring or generating while simultaneously providing brushless power to the rotor winding set, the active current of the BWRSDF machine would be independent of the reactive impedance of the transformer circuit and bursts of torque significantly higher than the maximum operating torque and far beyond the practical capability of any other type of electric machine would be realizable. Torque bursts greater than <a3_0><b7_0>eight times operating torque<b7_0/><a3_0/> have been calculated.
